L1: # Agent Task
L2: 
L3: Task id: gcse-chemistry-8-9
L4: Task title: GCSE chemistry grade 8-9 multi-step quantitative solving
L5: Reference paper: GCSE Chemistry topic set (AQA specification-aligned, synthesized benchmark)
L6: Reference URL: https://www.aqa.org.uk/subjects/science/gcse/chemistry-8462/specification-at-a-glance
L7: 
L8: ## Objective
L9: Read the report and produce all required JSON outputs that satisfy their schemas.
L10: 
L11: ## Inputs On Disk
L12: - Report: `input/report.md`
L13: - Schemas: in `schemas/`
L14: 
L15: ## Required Outputs
L16: - `output/problem_01.json` (schema: `schemas/problem_01.schema.json`)
L17: - `output/problem_02.json` (schema: `schemas/problem_02.schema.json`)
L18: - `output/problem_03.json` (schema: `schemas/problem_03.schema.json`)
L19: - `output/problem_04.json` (schema: `schemas/problem_04.schema.json`)
L20: - `output/problem_05.json` (schema: `schemas/problem_05.schema.json`)
L21: - `output/problem_06.json` (schema: `schemas/problem_06.schema.json`)
L22: 
L23: ## Constraints
L24: - Do not invent source facts; derive calculations only from values in the report.
L25: - Use line refs as `L<number>` where required.
L26: - Where quotes are required, copy exact report snippets.
L27: - For calculation outputs, line_refs must include every report line used for equations, constants, and numeric substitutions.
L28: - Use relative paths only.
L29: - Never use absolute paths.
L30: - Never use `..` in paths.
L31: - Write valid JSON only.
L32: 
L33: ## Completion
L34: Respond with a checklist of written output files.

input/
output/
schemas/

problem_06.schema.json

L1: # GCSE Chemistry Quantitative Challenge (Grade 8-9)
L2: 
L3: ## Provenance
L4: - Scope: GCSE Chemistry Higher Tier style quantitative problem set.
L5: - Benchmark note: This is a synthesized exam-style set aligned with AQA GCSE Chemistry (8462) quantitative topics.
L6: - Specification reference: https://www.aqa.org.uk/subjects/science/gcse/chemistry-8462/specification-at-a-glance
L7: 
L8: ## Instructions
L9: - Solve each problem from the given data only.
L10: - Use appropriate significant figures and clear working.
L11: - Use only equations/constants listed in this document.
L12: 
L13: ## Constants and Formula Reminders
L14: - Moles: n = m / Mr
L15: - Concentration: c = n / V (V in dm3)
L16: - Dilution: c1V1 = c2V2
L17: - Charge: Q = I * t
L18: - Moles of electrons: n(e-) = Q / F
L19: - Faraday constant: F = 96,500 C mol-1
L20: - At equilibrium for N2O4(g) <-> 2NO2(g): Kc = [NO2]^2 / [N2O4]
L21: - Report Kc as dimensionless (unitless).
L22: 
L23: ## Atomic / Formula Data
L24: - H = 1.0, C = 12.0, O = 16.0, S = 32.1, Ca = 40.1, Cu = 63.55
L25: - Mr(CaCO3) = 100.1
L26: - Mr(CO2) = 44.0
L27: 
L28: ## Problem P01 (Dilution)
L29: A technician transfers 25.0 cm3 of 0.200 mol dm-3 HCl into a volumetric flask and dilutes it with water to a final volume of 250.0 cm3.
L30: Find the new concentration of HCl in mol dm-3.
L31: 
L32: ## Problem P02 (Stoichiometry + Purity)
L33: Limestone sample mass = 5.00 g. The sample is 84.0% CaCO3 by mass.
L34: Reaction: CaCO3 + 2HCl -> CaCl2 + CO2 + H2O
L35: Assume acid is in excess.
L36: Calculate the maximum mass of CO2 that can be produced.
L37: 
L38: ## Problem P03 (Titration)
L39: 25.00 cm3 of H2SO4 is neutralized by 23.40 cm3 of 0.150 mol dm-3 NaOH.
L40: Reaction: H2SO4 + 2NaOH -> Na2SO4 + 2H2O
L41: Calculate the concentration of H2SO4 in mol dm-3.
L42: 
L43: ## Problem P04 (Bond Energy Estimate)
L44: Estimate deltaH for methane combustion using mean bond energies.
L45: Equation: CH4 + 2O2 -> CO2 + 2H2O
L46: Bond energies (kJ mol-1): C-H = 413, O=O = 498, C=O (in CO2) = 805, O-H = 463
L47: Use: deltaH = sum(bonds broken) - sum(bonds formed)
L48: 
L49: ## Problem P05 (Electrolysis)
L50: Copper is deposited during electrolysis of aqueous CuSO4 using inert electrodes.
L51: Current = 1.50 A, time = 30.0 min.
L52: Half-equation at cathode: Cu2+ + 2e- -> Cu
L53: Calculate the mass of copper deposited.
L54: 
L55: ## Problem P06 (Equilibrium Constant)
L56: For N2O4(g) <-> 2NO2(g), at equilibrium in a 2.00 dm3 vessel:
L57: - moles(NO2) = 0.180 mol
L58: - moles(N2O4) = 0.220 mol
L59: Calculate Kc.

steps.text:
[tool-call]\n{
  "id": "fc_0cb1c686ed94470c00698f41648a7881a3814fb9fe161df9bd",
  "type": "function_call",
  "status": "completed",
  "arguments": "{\"file_path\":\"output/problem_01.json\",\"content\":\"{\\n  \\\"problem_id\\\": \\\"P01\\\",\\n  \\\"final_answer\\\": {\\n    \\\"value\\\": 0.02,\\n    \\\"units\\\": \\\"mol dm-3\\\",\\n    \\\"precision_note\\\": \\\"Inputs are given to 3 s.f.; report the diluted concentration to 3 s.f. (0.0200 mol dm-3).\\\"\\n  },\\n  \\\"method\\\": \\\"Use the dilution relationship c1V1 = c2V2. The initial acid has c1 = 0.200 mol dm-3 and volume V1 = 25.0 cm3, diluted to final volume V2 = 250.0 cm3. Because both volumes are in cm3, the units cancel in the ratio V1/V2. Rearrange to c2 = c1 × V1/V2 = 0.200 × (25.0/250.0) = 0.200 × 0.100 = 0.0200 mol dm-3.\\\",\\n  \\\"key_equations\\\": [\\n    \\\"c1V1 = c2V2\\\",\\n    \\\"c2 = c1 × (V1/V2)\\\"\\n  ],\\n  \\\"line_refs\\\": [\\n    \\\"L16\\\",\\n    \\\"L29\\\"\\n  ],\\n  \\\"checks\\\": [\\n    \\\"Volume increases by a factor of 10 (25.0 → 250.0 cm3), so concentration should fall by 10×: 0.200/10 = 0.0200 mol dm-3.\\\"\\n  ]\\n}\\n\"}",
  "call_id": "call_HRfB9lJiA4o7sH7lNOs1INWu",
  "name": "write_file",
  "parsed_arguments": null
}\n[tool-call]\n{
  "id": "fc_0cb1c686ed94470c00698f41648a8481a3a214394638270bc0",
  "type": "function_call",
  "status": "completed",
  "arguments": "{\"file_path\":\"output/problem_02.json\",\"content\":\"{\\n  \\\"problem_id\\\": \\\"P02\\\",\\n  \\\"final_answer\\\": {\\n    \\\"value\\\": 1.85,\\n    \\\"units\\\": \\\"g\\\",\\n    \\\"precision_note\\\": \\\"Limiting data are 3 s.f. (5.00 g, 84.0%, 44.0, 100.1); report mass to 3 s.f.\\\"\\n  },\\n  \\\"method\\\": \\\"First find the mass of calcium carbonate present using the stated purity: m(CaCO3) = 5.00 g × 0.840 = 4.20 g. From the balanced equation CaCO3 + 2HCl → CaCl2 + CO2 + H2O, 1 mol CaCO3 produces 1 mol CO2. Convert from CaCO3 mass to CO2 mass using molar-mass ratios for the 1:1 mole relationship: m(CO2) = m(CaCO3) × Mr(CO2)/Mr(CaCO3) = 4.20 × (44.0/100.1) = 1.85 g (3 s.f.).\\\",\\n  \\\"key_equations\\\": [\\n    \\\"m(pure CaCO3) = m(sample) × purity\\\",\\n    \\\"For 1:1 CaCO3:CO2, m(CO2) = m(CaCO3) × Mr(CO2)/Mr(CaCO3)\\\"\\n  ],\\n  \\\"line_refs\\\": [\\n    \\\"L33\\\",\\n    \\\"L34\\\",\\n    \\\"L25\\\",\\n    \\\"L26\\\"\\n  ],\\n  \\\"checks\\\": [\\n    \\\"Only 4.20 g of CaCO3 is available, so CO2 produced must be less than this; 1.85 g is reasonable.\\\",\\n    \\\"Using moles: 4.20/100.1 ≈ 0.042 mol CaCO3, giving 0.042×44.0 ≈ 1.85 g CO2 (consistent).\\\"\\n  ]\\n}\\n\"}",

(0.150 mol dm-3, 23.40 cm3, 25.00 cm3); report concentration to 3 s.f.\\\"\\n  },\\n  \\\"method\\\": \\\"Convert the NaOH titre to dm3: 23.40 cm3 = 0.02340 dm3. Use c = n/V to get moles of NaOH: n(NaOH) = cV = 0.150 × 0.02340 = 0.00351 mol. From H2SO4 + 2NaOH → Na2SO4 + 2H2O, 2 mol NaOH neutralize 1 mol H2SO4, so n(H2SO4) = 0.00351/2 = 0.001755 mol. Convert acid volume: 25.00 cm3 = 0.02500 dm3. Then c(H2SO4) = n/V = 0.001755/0.02500 = 0.0702 mol dm-3.\\\",\\n  \\\"key_equations\\\": [\\n    \\\"c = n / V\\\",\\n    \\\"n = cV\\\",\\n    \\\"n(H2SO4) = n(NaOH)/2 (from 1:2 stoichiometry)\\\"\\n  ],\\n  \\\"line_refs\\\": [\\n    \\\"L15\\\",\\n    \\\"L39\\\",\\n    \\\"L40\\\"\\n  ],\\n  \\\"checks\\\": [\\n    \\\"Because 2 mol NaOH react per 1 mol H2SO4 and the volumes are similar, the acid concentration should be a bit under half the NaOH concentration; 0.0702 is slightly under 0.075 and is plausible.\\\",\\n    \\\"Recalculate quickly: (0.150×23.40/25.00)/2 ≈ (0.1404)/2 ≈ 0.0702 mol dm-3.\\\"\\n  ]\\n}\\n\"}",

  "arguments": "{\"file_path\":\"output/problem_04.json\",\"content\":\"{\\n  \\\"problem_id\\\": \\\"P04\\\",\\n  \\\"final_answer\\\": {\\n    \\\"value\\\": -814,\\n    \\\"units\\\": \\\"kJ mol-1\\\",\\n    \\\"precision_note\\\": \\\"Mean bond energies are given as whole-number kJ mol-1; report ΔH to 3 s.f. to reflect the estimates.\\\"\\n  },\\n  \\\"method\\\": \\\"Use ΔH = Σ(bonds broken) − Σ(bonds formed). For CH4 + 2O2 → CO2 + 2H2O: bonds broken are 4×(C–H) in CH4 and 2×(O=O) from 2O2. Broken energy = 4×413 + 2×498 = 1652 + 996 = 2648 kJ mol-1. Bonds formed are 2×(C=O) in CO2 and 4×(O–H) in 2H2O (each H2O has two O–H bonds). Formed energy = 2×805 + 4×463 = 1610 + 1852 = 3462 kJ mol-1. Therefore ΔH = 2648 − 3462 = −814 kJ mol-1 (exothermic).\\\",\\n  \\\"key_equations\\\": [\\n    \\\"ΔH = Σ(bonds broken) − Σ(bonds formed)\\\"\\n  ],\\n  \\\"line_refs\\\": [\\n    \\\"L45\\\",\\n    \\\"L46\\\",\\n    \\\"L47\\\"\\n  ],\\n  \\\"checks\\\": [\\n    \\\"Combustion reactions should be exothermic, so a negative ΔH is expected.\\\",\\n    \\\"Magnitude is in the typical hundreds of kJ mol-1 for hydrocarbon combustion, so −814 kJ mol-1 is reasonable for an estimate.\\\"\\n  ]\\n}\\n\"}",

Total charge passed is I×t = 1.50 × 1800 = 2700 C. Convert charge to moles of electrons using the Faraday constant: n(e−) = 2700/96500 = 0.02798 mol e−. From the cathode half-equation Cu2+ + 2e− → Cu, 2 mol e− deposit 1 mol Cu, so n(Cu) = 0.02798/2 = 0.01399 mol. Mass deposited = n × Ar(Cu) = 0.01399 × 63.55 = 0.8887 g ≈ 0.889 g.\\\",\\n  \\\"key_equations\\\": [\\n    \\\"n(e−) = (I × t) / F\\\",\\n    \\\"For Cu2+ + 2e− → Cu: n(Cu) = n(e−)/2\\\",\\n    \\\"m = n × Ar\\\"\\n  ],\\n  \\\"line_refs\\\": [\\n    \\\"L51\\\",\\n    \\\"L19\\\",\\n    \\\"L52\\\",\\n    \\\"L24\\\"\\n  ],\\n  \\\"checks\\\": [\\n    \\\"Order-of-magnitude check: 1.50 A for 1800 s gives 2700 C; dividing by ~10^5 gives ~0.03 mol e−, so ~0.015 mol Cu, which is ~1 g — consistent with 0.889 g.\\\",\\n    \\\"If the time or current doubled, mass would double; the linear dependence on I and t matches electrolysis expectations.\\\"\\n  ]\\n}\\n\"}",
  "call_id": "call_Dg4Is2OslUp6nE0SvheBbQ0Q",
  "name": "write_file",

  "arguments": "{\"file_path\":\"output/problem_06.json\",\"content\":\"{\\n  \\\"problem_id\\\": \\\"P06\\\",\\n  \\\"final_answer\\\": {\\n    \\\"value\\\": 0.0736,\\n    \\\"units\\\": \\\"unitless\\\",\\n    \\\"precision_note\\\": \\\"Moles and volume are given to 3 s.f.; report Kc to 3 s.f. and as dimensionless.\\\"\\n  },\\n  \\\"method\\\": \\\"For N2O4(g) ⇌ 2NO2(g), Kc = [NO2]^2/[N2O4]. Using concentrations [X] = n/V, substitute to eliminate concentration calculation: Kc = ( (n(NO2)/V)^2 ) / (n(N2O4)/V ) = n(NO2)^2 / (n(N2O4) × V). With n(NO2)=0.180 mol, n(N2O4)=0.220 mol, V=2.00 dm3: Kc = (0.180^2) / (0.220 × 2.00) = 0.0324 / 0.440 = 0.073636... = 0.0736 (3 s.f.).\\\",\\n  \\\"key_equations\\\": [\\n    \\\"Kc = [NO2]^2 / [N2O4]\\\",\\n    \\\"Kc = n(NO2)^2 / (n(N2O4) × V)  (since [X]=n/V)\\\"\\n  ],\\n  \\\"line_refs\\\": [\\n    \\\"L20\\\",\\n    \\\"L56\\\",\\n    \\\"L57\\\",\\n    \\\"L58\\\"\\n  ],\\n  \\\"checks\\\": [\\n    \\\"Kc is small (<1), indicating equilibrium favours N2O4, consistent with having comparable moles but NO2 needing to be squared.\\\",\\n    \\\"Recompute via concentrations: [NO2]=0.180/2.00=0.0900, [N2O4]=0.220/2.00=0.110; Kc=(0.0900^2)/0.110 ≈ 0.0736 (matches).\\\"\\n  ]\\n}\\n\"}",
  "call_id": "call_zoHZ4YvXHYaE30dQWE4hgQS0",
  "name": "write_file",
  "parsed_arguments": null
}\n

input.content:
{
  "problem_id": "P05",
  "final_answer": {
    "value": 0.889,
    "units": "g",
    "precision_note": "I and t are 3 s.f. and Cu Ar is 4–5 s.f.; report deposited mass to 3 s.f."
  },
  "method": "Convert time to seconds: 30.0 min = 30.0 × 60 = 1800 s. Total charge passed is I×t = 1.50 × 1800 = 2700 C. Convert charge to moles of electrons using the Faraday constant: n(e−) = 2700/96500 = 0.02798 mol e−. From the cathode half-equation Cu2+ + 2e− → Cu, 2 mol e− deposit 1 mol Cu, so n(Cu) = 0.02798/2 = 0.01399 mol. Mass deposited = n × Ar(Cu) = 0.01399 × 63.55 = 0.8887 g ≈ 0.889 g.",
  "key_equations": [
    "n(e−) = (I × t) / F",
    "For Cu2+ + 2e− → Cu: n(Cu) = n(e−)/2",
    "m = n × Ar"
  ],
  "line_refs": [
    "L51",
    "L19",
    "L52",
    "L24"
  ],
  "checks": [
    "Order-of-magnitude check: 1.50 A for 1800 s gives 2700 C; dividing by ~10^5 gives ~0.03 mol e−, so ~0.015 mol Cu, which is ~1 g — consistent with 0.889 g.",
    "If the time or current doubled, mass would double; the linear dependence on I and t matches electrolysis expectations."
  ]
}
